review_blob: On cask at The Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Clear gold, with a minimal frothy off-white head. A heady and pungent aroma of tropical fruit. Full-on flavours of sweet tropical, (particularly over-ripe mango) and citrus fruit. A long zesty, dry finish.

On cask at the Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Dark gold with a minimal head. A lovely full-on marmaladey aroma. Quite full on the palate with some Crme brulee type flavours balanced by some very citrussy hops. Bitter overall, but very drinkable.

On cask at the Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Amber coloured with a medium slightly off-white tight head. Malty aroma with some subtle caramel. Quite full-bodied for its strength. No shortage of flavours; malty toffee balanced with plenty of piney hops. Good session bitter.

On cask at the Three Fishes in Shrewsbury on 10th of April 2016. Very pale with a tight white head. Some subtle citrus aromas, but quite subdued overall. Very light in body and in flavour, with some grapefruity and general citrussy flavours. Very much a summer quaffer, not offering enough oomph for me at the moment.
From a can. Pours with a flat head. Lovely aroma, reminiscent of Sorachi Ace. Surprisingly good and Ill be drinking it again.
From a bottle. Pours with a nice frothy head. Pale gold. Lovely fresh aroma. Creamy, with a viscous mouthfeel. Loving this all round.

From a bottle, probably the only batch. Pours flat. Reddish, typical barleywine-ish colour. Aroma is barleywine-ish followed by cobwebs. Disappointing on the palate, not a lot going on. Cobwebbish. :-(
From a bottle. Pours pretty flat. Opaque. Lovely aroma. Fortunately I do like this style (Porter) and the subtle Chilli is a plus. Great!
From a bottle. Pours with a decent head. Good aroma, however theres something lurking which is a bit unpleasant. Lively, dry and bitter. Decent!

From a bottle. Pours with a tight flat head. Murky pale gold. Wow, the aroma is incredible; so much going on for 4.2%.... Like a slightly sour barrel-aged Belgian. Reminiscent of a wine barrel-aged beer I tasted recently. Lively and completely belying its Abv and everything else. A completely unexpected delight. #flashinthepan
From a bottle. Minimal wispy head. Murky dull amber. Little aroma, cobwebby cardboard. On the palate.... Cardboard. This cannot be a good example.
From a bottle. Pours with a minimal frothy head. Murky orangey/amber. Lovely lifted aromas. Lively, great malt/hop balance and a good hoppy finish.

From a bottle. Pours with a very minimal slightly frothy head. Slightly hazy pale amber. Aromas of green apples and pears, with an underlying stemmy vegetal unpleasantness. Decent effervescence and plenty of flavour. Some citrussy orangey elements. Not sure this is the finished article.

From a bottle. Pours slightly hazy with almost no head. Immediately there is an aroma consistent with a cask ale that hasnt been pulled all day. Vague fruity hops, but mostly vegetal/foliage aromas. This must have a fault.
From a bottle. Pours almost flat. Opaque black. Thin, light with some subtle roast and saltiness. Easy drinking with no stand out flavours.
beer_name: Waen Drawn to the Deep End

review_blob: On cask at The Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Dark amber with an off white frothy head. Malty on the nose with nutty and bready aromas. Malty palate with some sweet nuttiness and some darker roast malt flavours. Good hop balance for a decent dry finish.
From a growler, ex brewery. Opaque mahogany in colour with a thin and quickly dissipating head. Coffee on the nose. Coffee and saltiness on the palate. Strange!

On cask at The Three Fishes in Shrewsbury on the 27th of February. Slightly murky yellow gold with a frothy white head. Lovely tropical fruit aroma, with a hint of marmalade. Great balance of malt and hops.
On cask at The Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury on the 26th of February. Golden with white head. Quite intense citrussy flavoured pale with a lasting piney finish.

On cask at the Salopian Bar, Shrewsbury. Clear gold with a white head. A heady alcoholic aroma is immediately apparent. Some citrus (grapefruit) and orangey notes. Surprisingly easy to drink for its strength.

On cask at The Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Deep red in colour with cream frothy head. Malty and fruity on the nose. Slightly cheesy, sweaty and hints of red wine and pork sausage on the palate. Weird!

On cask at The Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Deep gold in colour with a minimal head. No obvious typical upfront Oakham aromas, quite subtle. Mellow on the palate with a creamy, buttery taste, reminiscent of Sorachi Ace. A bit different for an Oakham beer.

On cask at The Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Pale gold, some light floral notes on the nose, but fairly subdued overall. Smooth on the palate, no spikey hoppiness; presumably the oatmeal influence. Good easy drinker.
On cask at The Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Amber, with a frothy head. Malty, but still very hoppy. Bitter orange and some slightly burnt malt flavours. Very quaffable.
On cask at The Woodman in Shrewsbury. Pale straw, minimal white head. Pretty dry overall, biscuity hints and some citrussy notes. One of their better pales in my opinion.
From a bottle at home. Murky amber with a small head. Very aromatic, orangey with some tropical fruit hit. Big flavours of bitter (seville) orange and mango with spicey rye. Drying on the finish.
From a bottle at home. Murky pale gold with a decent white head. A mixed tropical fruity nose, following onto the palate; mango, pineapple, grapefruit and passion fruit. Some sweetness on the finish.

On cask at The Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Very pale yellow, minimal off-white head. Intense citrus nose; bathroom cleaner, air freshener. Lovely citrus and pine flavours on the palate with some subtle biscuity malt. Fantastic balance and eminently quaffable, a true classic.

On cask at The Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Pale straw in colour with a small off-white head. Mostly grapefruit on the nose, with a hint of green olive. Bitter on the palate with some more grapefruity notes. Drying finish. Perhaps a little one dimensional.
From a can at The Vaults in Shrewsbury. Lovely intense pineapple and citrus aromas. Big citrussy flavours and plenty of hop bite on the finish. A classic.

On cask at The Dolphin in Shrewsbury. Amber in colour with a small white-ish head. A slightly honeyed nose with some biscuity aromas. A bit dull on the palate, again slightly honeyed, with a lack of bite. Either nearing the end or just a bit dull.

On cask at The Dolphin in Shrewsbury. Crystal clear and pale straw in colour with a small white head. Delicate fruity aroma, not a lot to speak of though. Light on the palate, some delicate citrussy elements and residual sugariness. Easy session beer.

From a bottle at The Vaults in Shrewsbury. A reddish/deep amber colour with an decent off-white head. Nice mixed fruits on the nose.... Citrus; orange and some berries. Plenty of harmonious malt, caramel and hops with orangey flavours leading. Deceptively hoppy on the finish, quite refreshing for a strong, darkish bitter.

From a bottle at The Vaults in Shrewsbury. A careless pour by myself resulted in lots of sediment, making this a murky bright gold, with a substantial white head. Full on grapefruit dominates on the nose. Again grapefruit is very noticeable on the palate, with some other underlying citrussy flavours. A great IPA like refresher with great balance.

From a bottle at Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Deep chestnut in colour, clear with a flat head. Acrid! Follows onto the palate, massively sour; vinegar and indescribable taste. Delicious.... A paradoxical beer.

From a bottle at Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Slightly murky pale chestnut in colour with a very tight off white head. Whisky aromas dominate initially, subsiding to candied fruit aromas. Mouthfeel is full, plenty of sweetness, some obvious whisky influence, but far from overpowering. Incredibly smooth and warming.
beer_name: La Trappe Quadrupel Oak Aged Batch #22

review_blob: From a can at Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Unsurprisingly, grapefruit is written all over this, from the initial aromas, right through to the finish. Its not subtle, so if grapefruit isnt your thing, dont bother.

From a bottle at Appleyards in Shrewsbury. Obviously dark, pours with small head. Good caramel and chocolatey aromas with a hint of coffee. Plenty of caramel, with sweet chocolate and then some subtle coffee notes on the palate. A good non-cloying finish.

On cask in the Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Clear pale gold, little head retention. Damp straw and some fruity elements on the nose, suggests high level of alcohol. Very bitter on the palate, good mouthfeel. Drying finish, needs food.

On cask in the Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Clear pale/blonde with minimal head retention. Slightly fruity aroma, suggesting some aromatic hops. Fresh and citrussy on the palate, lime being the dominant flavour on offer. Gentle but refreshing hoppy finish.
On cask at the Three Fishes in Shrewsbury. Clear blonde with decent white head. Hints of caramel on the subdued nose. Easy drinking, smooth, malty with gentle hops.

On keg at Montgomerys Tower in Shrewsbury. Cloudy yellow in appearance with a dense white head. Very aromatic..... Mixed citrus fruits, orangey-ness standing out. Served a touch too cold, masking some of the flavours, but some mango and orange flavours were coming through. Lots of bite on the finish.

Bottle-conditioned at home. Pours with a good head. Amber with a slight haze. Subdued on the nose, but offering floral notes. Medium bodied, leaning towards a slightly maltier, sweeter bitter. Drying on the finish.
beer_name: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbodys Bosbury Best

review_blob: From a bottle at Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Amber in colour, slightly hazy and a dense head. Pronounced fruity aromas; apricot, mango and a tiny hint of apricot stones/marzipan. Follows onto the palate with a creamy mouthfeel and a slightly buttery element, suggesting barrel ageing. Not too hoppy, good malt balance.

330ml bottle from Appleyards in Shrewsbury. Clear, deep pink in colour. Lovely fragrant raspberries on the nose with some obvious sourness. Light on the palate with obvious raspberry fruit and delicate tartness. Subtle sweetness leading into a drying finish.

From a bottle at Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Dark ruby with a substantial head. Not a particularly big aroma, but getting some caramel and subtle spiced fruit. Big, rich mouthfeel with gingery, plummy fruitcake flavours, fading a little to a slightly disappointing finish.

From a can in Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Hazy pale gold in appearance. Perfect level of carbonation. Lovely fresh aroma with fruity hints. Gentle on the palate, with only a touch of salt, and gooseberry sourness. Easy drinker.
On Keg in Chez Sophie in Shrewsbury. Hazy pale gold in appearance. Peachy perfumed aromas. Light body, good balance, not aggressively hopped.
On cask at the Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury. Heady tropical aromas. Rich and full on the palate, intense fruity flavours leading to sweetness. A long powerful hoppy finish.
